parameter 1: In the wake of Walt's death, the show was modified to provide an alternate narration explaining Donald's quitting and subsequent return to the Studio. An edited 30-minute version aired in 1982.
parameter 2: This episode originally aired in black and white, but later reaired in color and then released on video and laser disc under a new title, "On Vacation With Mickey Mouse and Friends".
parameter 3: When it first aired, the Mickey Mouse Club segment that the nephews watch on TV was the original 1950s version. When it re-aired in the 1970s and '80s, however, it was updated to feature the 1977 version of the show.
parameter 4: The long out of print Disney VHS tape (USA version, at least) is not cut, but runs two hours and nine minutes, and contains all of the three-part TV serial except for episode breaks and original opening and closing credits, playing as a continuous feature with the theatrical release titles. Cinema prints of this film do omit material and run only 98 minutes. It was once shown in the mid-70s on the "World of Disney" broadcast network TV show as a two-parter, missing the middle episode in which the Scarecrow deals with a traitor among his men.
parameter 5: In the wake of Walt's death, the show was modified to provide an alternate narration explaining Donald's quitting and subsequent return to the Studio. An edited 30-minute version aired in 1982.
parameter 6: After Walt's death, the opening was modified to prove a new narration explaining the presence of the guest hosts.
parameter 7: This was shown in America as a two part episode of "The Wonderful World of Color" on NBC television.
parameter 8: The original version of this cartoon had 'Dinah Shore' (qv) narrating the story, not Jiminy Cricket.
parameter 9: The "stereophonic" version of this episode begins with _Walt Disney_ (qv) recalling different firsts in Disney history, then proclaiming that this marks the first TV broadcast with widescreen clips and stereophonic audio. He proceeds to instruct the viewers on how to set up their radios to enjoy the broadcast. Viewers who could only watch this episode in mono audio saw an introduction with Walt skipping over these instructions.
parameter 10: Parts 1 and 2 were released together theatrically overseas as a complete film.
parameter 11: The original version of this cartoon had 'Dinah Shore' (qv) narrating the story, not Jiminy Cricket.
parameter 12: This episode originally aired in black and white, but later reaired in color and then released on video and laser disc under a new title, "On Vacation With Mickey Mouse and Friends".
parameter 13: When it first aired, the Mickey Mouse Club segment that the nephews watch on TV was the original 1950s version. When it re-aired in the 1970s and '80s, however, it was updated to feature the 1977 version of the show.
parameter 14: When it re-aired in 1970, all scenes with Walt's and Tinker Bell's intros, as well as the short _Santa's Workshop (1932)_ (qv), had been replaced by a teaser for _The AristoCats (1970)_ (qv).
parameter 15: The three "Prince and the Pauper" episodes were released as one full-length theatrical film, "The Prince and the Pauper", in Europe.

parameter 30: When this episode reaired in syndication and was released on home video, it was retitled "Ducking Disaster With Donald and His Friends".
parameter 31: The original 1950s version of this episode ended with Willie the Giant still looking for Mickey, picking up the Studio roof and asking Walt of the mouse's whereabouts. This ending scene was omitted after Walt's death.
parameter 32: This episode originally aired in black and white, but later reaired in color and then released on video and laser disc under a new title, "On Vacation With Mickey Mouse and Friends".
parameter 33: The original airing of this episode featured the black centaurette in the Pastoral Symphony scene. This centaurette, however, was deleted from this episode when it aired on The Disney Channel. Some earlier airings would retain later appearances of the centaurette, such as during the storm, while later airings would delete this character altogether.
